name: John Horgan
tweet: Due to the extreme risk of wildfires, there is a campfire ban in place. Failing to follow this ban can lead to serious fines and penalties.

name: John Horgan

name: John Horgan
tweet: Having an addiction is not a crime & shouldn‚Äôt be treated as such. We also continue adding treatment options to get people the care they need.  This will be phased in. It follows work with experts, including doctors, nurses, people with lived experience & Indigenous-led orgs.

name: John Horgan
tweet: This is about saving lives.  BC is introducing a new prescribed safer supply policy. We're the first in North America to take this approach, which will reduce the risk of toxic drug death.  It's just one tool in our comprehensive response to the overdose crisis.

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're committed to supporting the vital research by First Nations at former residential school sites in BC. This includes $12 million in new funding for research, as well as mental health and cultural supports. We continue to follow their lead on the appropriate way forward.

name: John Horgan

name: John Horgan
tweet: This is vile, racist behaviour. If this is how you treat people, you are the problem.  Racism is a scourge and we must stand together against it to build a better province.

tweet: With so much heartache for people in Lytton, I'm glad Jessica could have this moment of incredible joy being reunited with her dog Princess.  https://t.co/X1aVUhd41J

name: John Horgan
tweet: As the pain is felt for this discovery, we know it also reignites the intergenerational trauma inflicted by colonialism. Let us continue to face these truths head on, and we stand ready do everything we can to help people heal.

name: John Horgan

name: John Horgan

tweet: Let us not turn away from the past, let us honour this important moment of healing in Lower Post.  We'll keep working together toward reconciliation and a better future.  https://t.co/imLvG7gCBE

tweet: It was my first @HarbourAirLtd flight in awhile - nice to share a quick snack before heading to the otter side of the Salish Sea.  https://t.co/KyGXfSynv1

name: John Horgan
tweet: Encouraging news: more British Columbians are working today than before the pandemic hit.  While BC's recovery is leading üá®üá¶, there‚Äôs more to do for those disproportionately affected. We're providing the most support for people and businesses per capita, so no one is left behind.

name: John Horgan

One of the many values we share is a commitment to making sure all orders of government work together to deliver the services people need. name: John Horgan
tweet: Firefighers and emergency workers have been tireless in their efforts to keep people safe here in BC. We're grateful for this additional support to protect British Columbians.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Last fall, we promised to get this built for people south of the Fraser ‚Äì and already announced funding for the business plan & early work.  It'll create good jobs & reduce pollution by offering a cleaner way to get around.  With Ottawa now in support, we can take a step forward.

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're a step closer to delivering on the Surrey ‚û°Ô∏è Langley SkyTrain.  People are getting back to commuting to work or school and coming together with family and friends.  It's critical we work in partnership to build the better, faster transit options British Columbians deserve.

name: John Horgan
tweet: When we formed government in 2017, child care was in chaos. Now the fastest creation of spaces in BC's history is well underway - and we're going to get to the universal $10-a-day system families deserve even faster.  https://t.co/wKaYskfY9A

name: John Horgan
tweet: We wouldn't be making the progress we are today for BC families without the leadership of these strong women in our @bcndp government.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Congratulations to newly elected AFN National Chief @RoseAnne4NC - the 1st woman to serve in the role. I look forward to continuing our work together making strides toward true reconciliation & further implementing the Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous People Act here in BC

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're just three years in to our 10-year plan to make child care more affordable and accessible, and it's already been life-changing for families. ¬† ‚úÖ Saving parents up to $1,600/mo ‚úÖ Funding 26,000 new spaces ‚úÖ Giving early childhood educators a well-deserved raise

name: John Horgan
tweet: We know what it takes to build a universal child care system in BC because it's happening right now.  By working together with the federal government to make $10-a-day child care a reality for families, we're helping build a stronger recovery for everyone.

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're taking action so renters no longer face eviction notices for bogus renovations that were never going to happen.  There's more to do, but we're protecting renters across BC: üö´ Stopping illegal renovictions ‚úÖ Rent freeze through 2021 ü§ù Better process to resolve disputes

name: John Horgan
tweet: I want to express my condolences to family and friends of Asa Singh Johal on his passing at the age of 98.  A role model to so many, and member of the Order of BC and Canada, his generosity and commitment to lifting others up is inspirational. He will be greatly missed.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The climate crisis is real. As a result, there will be more intense heat waves in BC's future.   We've made important progress on climate change through our CleanBC plan, but there's much more work ahead of us.  https://t.co/GF3GMnXyBo

name: John Horgan
tweet: Deeply moving to see firsthand the damage to Lytton and speak to people displaced from their homes. name: John Horgan
tweet: Congratulations to Governor General Mary Simon on her historic appointment! I join all British Columbians in celebrating Ms. Simon's impressive career & expertise she will bring, as well as being the first Indigenous and Inuk person to serve in this role.  https://t.co/363MjnJr5l

name: John Horgan
tweet: The Daylu Dena Council, Liard FN, Taku River Tlingit FN, the Tahltan and Kaska people, & residential school survivors across the North marked the start of a new era.  It's a profound honour to be invited to witness. I was humbled in the presence of such strength and perseverance.  https://t.co/ntGo5phFLn

name: John Horgan
tweet: For a quarter-century, the residential school was a place of horrendous trauma for children stolen from their families.  Even after that, the community was had to use the building. For many Elders, it meant returning to the very rooms they were abused in.  https://t.co/mYgTBinrCF

name: John Horgan
tweet: Together with survivors, families, community members and Indigenous leaders, we witnessed ceremonial demolition of the Lower Post Residential School last week.  Then, a blessing of the ground for a new cultural centre that will be a place of healing and celebration.  https://t.co/83f8fyB1Pg

name: John Horgan
tweet: Moving forward with reconciliation does not mean forgetting events of the past. It means telling the truth of our history and learning from it, so we can build a better future for everyone.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The kindness and generosity of British Columbians never ceases to amaze me. Thank you for looking out for each other.   The BC government is focused on supporting evacuees and will be there to help rebuild Lytton.  We will get through this together.  https://t.co/a5OkPc0xYN

name: John Horgan
tweet: Burning down churches is not the way forward. All places of community worship must be protected. It is only by coming together that we can support one another. Vandalism will not move us forward. Respect and understanding will.   https://t.co/BQ4zojGCbA

name: John Horgan
tweet: I was pleased to welcome the Prime Minister‚Äôs commitment yesterday of federal support to BC‚Äôs wildfire response, including military response where needed.  https://t.co/wypoJPOU0g

name: John Horgan
tweet: I also want to express my gratitude to those who've provided food and shelter for the evacuees - in Lillooet, Merritt, Boston Bar, Chilliwack, Kamloops and elsewhere.  There's nothing more Canadian than offering safety and refuge at a time of great need. Thank you.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Thank you to the firefighters bravely battling fires across BC, many of whom are from Lytton and don't know what has become of their homes. You have the support of all British Columbians.

name: John Horgan
tweet: This is heartbreaking news. My deepest condolences are with this couple‚Äôs family and friends right now.  https://t.co/X19iJuLQV1

name: John Horgan
tweet: We cannot stress enough how extreme the fire risk is in BC right now. Under current conditions, fires can quickly overwhelm our firefighting resources.  One of the best things right now for all of us to thank firefighters is to do everything we can to prevent causing any new ones

name: John Horgan
tweet: We will get through this. By continuing to work together, listening to the best advice of officials, and helping our family, friends and neighbours.

name: John Horgan
tweet: When the smoke clears in Lytton, when the damage is assessed and when we are sure that people are safe, the Government of BC will be there to help rebuild the town of Lytton.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Lytton was hit with overlapping emergencies, this fire hit after three consecutive days of a record heat wave.  We're still assessing the damage and will provide more information as soon as we can.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Our thoughts are with the people of Lytton and all British Columbians in communities who've had to evacuate or are facing dangerous fire risk. I know you're deeply concerned about the well-being of your families, neighbours and homes.  Our number one focus is to keep people safe.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Let's commit to meaningful actions of reconciliation with Indigenous peoples. Let's do more to welcome people from all over the world, recognizing diversity is one of our greatest strengths.  We have hard work ahead of us. But a more just and inclusive Canada is worth the effort.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Because we've looked out for each other, we can see the end of the pandemic & safely come together with family & friends.  We've also been reminded of the intergenerational trauma inflicted by colonialism & the systemic racism that remains a lived reality for too many.

name: John Horgan
tweet: This #CanadaDay, we have things to be grateful for and even more to reflect on.  There's a lot of work ahead of us to live up to our shared values of fairness, kindness and generosity.  https://t.co/cmdQIb9nR4

name: John Horgan
tweet: The fire situation is extremely dangerous right now. Emergency crews are doing everything they can to support the people of Lytton. Please follow the latest updates from @BCGovFireInfo and @EmergencyInfoBC.  https://t.co/DOaqmXDemn

name: John Horgan
tweet: The residents of Lower Post suffer fear, anger and sadness at the sight of the residential school in their community. I encourage you to read this essay from Lianne Marie Leda Charlie, the daughter of a residential school survivor.  https://t.co/yRaEKTBV8H

name: John Horgan

name: John Horgan
tweet: Tomorrow will be a powerful day. Local leaders are planning a collective ceremony, bringing together survivors from across northern BC, to tear down the residential school. We will bear witness, and move forward together with renewed hope. ¬† Because every child matters.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The Daylu Dena Council has advocated tirelessly for a new community centre, and in 2019 we committed to help them build one of healing, hope and well-being. ¬† We were honoured to announce we were moving forward in partnership this spring.  https://t.co/q2Qi8nOFlp

name: John Horgan
tweet: It's extremely important to listen to the stories of residential school survivors. name: John Horgan
tweet: We will continue working with health authorities to help British Columbians take precautions against the heat. Please encourage your friends and family to follow these safety tips:  https://t.co/i8HLn3Vjrp

name: John Horgan
tweet: Nothing can ease the pain of losing a loved one, whether it's from the unprecedented heat wave or any other cause.  Mourning families deserve our compassion, and the wording of my comments didn't reflect that.  Please continue supporting one another & checking on your neighbours.

name: John Horgan
tweet: As exciting as BC's Restart is, it may feel strange for some. For example, many people and businesses may not be ready to do away with masks - and that's okay.  We need to respect different comfort levels and personal situations as we move forward together.

name: John Horgan
tweet: From cheering on our kids playing sports, to going out for dinner with more friends, or holding a festivals with safety plans in place.  We're also ready to safely open our doors to the rest of Canada.

name: John Horgan
tweet: People in BC have stepped up to get vaccinated, with our coverage among the highest in the world. We can safely start doing more things with more people, as we did before the pandemic.  On July 1, we will begin Step 3 of BC's Restart.   https://t.co/b4f8mdRqfn  https://t.co/3eeHAjBUs9

tweet: Along with the federal government and @fnha, we will continue to support and follow the lead of First Nations in acknowledging these atrocities and honouring the spirit of so many stolen children.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The sites of former residential schools are a source of unanswered questions and terrible pain.  We're providing new funding to support First Nations throughout BC with their investigations at these sites, as well as cultural and wellness supports for those experiencing trauma.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Vaccines are working. Better days are just around the corner.  https://t.co/VL9CeJ5QQO

name: John Horgan
tweet: We continue working together w/ First Nations rights & title holders on more deferrals, in addition to Fairy Creek watershed + 10 other areas we protected that would've been logged under BC Liberals. ¬† We're committed to protecting old growth forests for future generations.

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're taking the next steps to protect BC's old growth forests.  A new panel of independent technical experts will ensure we're using the best science and data available to identify at-risk ecosystems and prioritize areas for deferral.

name: John Horgan
tweet: There are many other sites in our province and country that are the source of unanswered questions and deep pain for Indigenous communities.  We stand ready to support the Tk‚Äôeml√∫ps te Secw√©pemc and any First Nation in BC seeking to bring full truth to these atrocities.

name: John Horgan
tweet: This isn't just history. Systemic racism and intergenerational trauma are a lived reality for Indigenous peoples to this day, inflicted by colonialism.  For future generations, we have a responsibility to face these shameful impacts head on today.

name: John Horgan
tweet: It's with heavy hearts we learn of hundreds of unmarked graves at a former residential school in SK.  These children were stolen from their families. We share the terrible grief with residential school survivors, families and Indigenous communities. We support you.

name: John Horgan
tweet: We must protect everyone‚Äôs right to feel welcome and safe in British Columbia, while constantly working to build a better country.  https://t.co/cicFGiuwjR

name: John Horgan
tweet: For those of us who have never been targeted because of our religion, ethnicity, sexuality or race, we can only imagine the daily traumas experienced by our fellow British Columbians.  We all have a responsibility ‚Äì especially those of us with privilege ‚Äì to care for one another.

name: John Horgan
tweet: More than 30yrs later, we still grapple with the senseless loss of life aboard Air India Flight182.  We honour the victims of this tragedy & all whose lives have been violently disrupted by terrorism, including those grieving the family killed because of their faith in London, ON

name: John Horgan
tweet: Cancer a difficult journey for so many BC families. I'm overjoyed for my friend, colleague and BC Finance Minister @selinarobinson and her loved ones to hear she's no longer a cancer patient.  From one survivor to another, congratulations Selina!

name: John Horgan

name: John Horgan
tweet: People are the economy. Share your ideas in the weeks ahead so that, together, we can build a stronger future that works for all British Columbians.

tweet: On National #IndigenousPeoplesDay, we honour & celebrate the culture, traditions & achievements of First Nations, Inuit & M√©tis peoples. name: John Horgan
tweet: Congratulations to Justice Jamal on this historic appointment!  https://t.co/j154L4ZKlG

name: John Horgan
tweet: Thanks to the efforts of everyone in the K-12 system, BC is one of the few jurisdictions that has been able to safely keep schools open.  We'll keep working together with health experts, educators and parents to keep students safe, help them learn, and support their well-being.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Students can look forward to:  ‚úÖ being in the classroom full-time ‚úÖ more mental health and learning supports ‚úÖ renewed investment in health and safety measures  More details on masks and other safety guidelines will be released later in the summer.

name: John Horgan
tweet: It's been a different school year for everyone, including students. Parents, teachers and staff worked tirelessly to adapt and support kids. Keeping everyone safe is our #1 priority.  Now, families and teachers can plan for a near-normal return to school this fall.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Step 2 of BC's Restart means safely reconnecting with friends and family, visiting more of our favourite places and celebrating the milestones we‚Äôve missed.  Learn more:  https://t.co/b4f8mdzOQN  https://t.co/WQioCsZM2k

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're getting closer to putting the pandemic behind us, but keeping people safe is still the #1 priority. We look forward to the federal government providing details and timelines on a safe and gradual reopening of Canada's borders.  https://t.co/mP5EHINBr3

name: John Horgan
tweet: As we look forward to the better days ahead, we're helping more people explore BC Parks while staying safe and protecting the environment.  https://t.co/9buu9SnSLf

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're committed to reconciliation and environmental protection - which we believe must go together.  In partnership with First Nations, we're going to keep doing the hard work necessary to protect BC's old growth forests for future generations.

name: John Horgan
tweet: This will protect the Fairy Creek watershed & central Walbran while FN titleholders build resource stewardship plans.  These are in addition to 200,000 hectares of old growth we‚Äôve protected that would've been logged under the BC Liberals ‚Äì equivalent to almost 500 Stanley Parks.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The first step in protecting old growth forests must be respecting Indigenous land management rights in their territories.  That's why we honour and approve the request from the Pacheedaht, Ditidaht & Huu-ay-aht to defer old growth logging, including the Fairy Creek watershed.  https://t.co/j1iqXdF1SW

name: John Horgan
tweet: Responsibly managed forests are a legacy for future generations.  We're taking this action to not only address the challenges facing forestry in BC today, but also so our children and grandchildren may benefit from the opportunities our forests provide.  https://t.co/NA6TZmUlkE

name: John Horgan
tweet: In partnership with First Nations, our new approach ensures the benefits of forestry are shared more widely with Indigenous people.  Our plan builds on progress we've made in adding to the 10 million hectares of old growth forests by deferring logging in even more areas of BC.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Ancient forests are our inheritance, and they will be our legacy.  We created the independent review, committed to implementing all recommendations, and took immediate action to protect 200,000 hectares of old growth left vulnerable by the BC Liberals.   But there's more to do.

name: John Horgan
tweet: Forests are at the heart of our identity in BC. But policies put in place two decades ago don't address today's challenges.  It's time for a new approach.  We're moving forward with a vision that's more environmentally sustainable, putting people and communities first.  https://t.co/RsoDOpbP80

name: John Horgan
tweet: For the first time in BC, we‚Äôre creating a permanent paid sick leave for every worker who is sick or injured.  https://t.co/7wZZ0NkX7X

name: John Horgan
tweet: By working together, we will get through this pandemic and continue building a strong recovery for everyone.

name: John Horgan
tweet: COVID-19 has exposed longstanding gaps in our communities & workplaces. It's not enough to return to how things were before.  That's why we're making life better for people once the pandemic is over with a long-term paid sick leave plan & consulting on which supports are needed.

name: John Horgan
tweet: What this means for workers: ‚û°Ô∏è If you need to stay home because of COVID-19, you will not lose pay.  What this means for businesses: ‚û°Ô∏è Businesses without an existing sick leave program will be reimbursed up to $200 per day/per worker.

name: John Horgan
tweet: The best way to protect workers, their families & communities is to have paid sick leave in place.  We advocated for a national plan to help workers across üá®üá¶, but the federal govt fell short. We're filling that gap with a made-in-BC plan to support workers & hard-hit businesses.

name: John Horgan
tweet: No one should ever have to choose between going to work sick and losing pay.  We're introducing three days paid sick leave to fight COVID-19 and moving toward a permanent system of paid leave for anyone who is sick or injured.

name: John Horgan
tweet: üì∫ Watch live: we're making sure workers are supported with paid sick leave through the pandemic and beyond.  https://t.co/NW9HDlnNvm

tweet: Through the largest investment in BC's history, we're working to ensure British Columbians can access the mental health and substance-use services and supports they need, when they need them.   https://t.co/MzdTVy3p72  https://t.co/ecmWRNi3LP

name: John Horgan
tweet: In solidarity with the family, friends and loved ones of the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada. On #RedDressDay, we honour their lives and recommit to ending the violence faced by far too many. #MMIWG

name: John Horgan
tweet: We're on track to get every eligible British Columbian their first vaccine dose by the end of June.  But to get there, we need everyone to register to get notified when it's their turn.  Retweet to help spread the word!

name: John Horgan
tweet: More than 41% of eligible people in BC have received a COVID-19 vaccine. Each one helps make our province safer.   Register for yours üëá

name: John Horgan
tweet: The best vaccine is the first one offered to you. I got mine as soon as I was eligible, so I could make everyone around me safer - and I challenge everyone in BC to do the same! Register online to get the vaccine. It's easy, safe and effective. #ThisIsOurShotCA  https://t.co/pL7RTee4px

name: John Horgan
tweet: We've made significant progress, but there's much more to do. By investing in people, we're building an economic recovery that includes everyone - not just those at the top. @AndrewMercierBC   https://t.co/HK40SYnIew

name: John Horgan
tweet: A new era begins today at ICBC. We're delivering on our commitment of major savings on your car insurance and significantly better care if you're in a crash.

name: John Horgan
tweet: From providing paid leave for vaccine appointments, to increasing the minimum wage and improving employment standards, we will continue to support fairness, equality and security for BC workers.  Happy #InternationalWorkersDay!

name: John Horgan
tweet: BC was a leader in advocating for a national paid sick leave program. While pleased Ottawa took up the challenge, we were disappointed it fell short.  Our govt is moving to fill the gaps to ensure BC workers won't have to choose between a paycheque & staying home when sick.

name: John Horgan
tweet: As we honour working people in BC and the fight for workers' rights, we recognize the effects of the pandemic have been felt disproportionately by women, people of colour, and those in the gig economy.  We've taken steps to better support workers, but there's much more to do.
